SystemOutput:
HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts lately, with fatigue, lightheadedness, and bloating. These symptoms have been present for about five weeks. He has been involved in home renovation projects and has had some difficulty maintaining a healthy diet due to the construction in his kitchen. He denies fever, chills, and abdominal pain but endorses shortness of breath during exertion and slight chest cramps that resolve after about an hour. The patient has a slight cough, which he attributes to the change of seasons.

The patient has been monitoring his blood pressure at home and reports that it has been well-controlled.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Fatigue, lightheadedness.
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath during exertion, slight chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Slight cough.
• Gastrointestinal: Bloating.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital signs: Blood pressure, heart rate, and oxygenation within normal limits.
• Neck: Jugular venous distention to 8 centimeters.
• Heart: 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Lungs: Fine crackles at bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by physical exam findings and chest X-ray.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily and call if weight gain or shortness of breath occurs. Order another echocardiogram.

2. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Instruct the patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations via the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. She states she was changing a light bulb on a ladder and stumbled, twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. The incident occurred yesterday. She has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but it does not seem to help much. She has a history of atrial fibrillation and takes digoxin. She has a past surgical history of a nose job. She denies any allergies.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. Pain is elicited with valgus stressing and flexion of the knee. Normal sensation is present. No calf pain.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right knee obtained on today's visit show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION:

Acute medial meniscus strain.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended we place her in a knee brace and provide crutches for temporary use. She will follow up in 1 week for re-evaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg, to be taken every 6 hours with food, for a two-week supply.

All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

The patient states he was helping his daughter with heavy equipment and lifted some boxes too quickly, causing pain in his lower back. This happened on Saturday morning, and he experienced a pop in his back followed by pain. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat without significant relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon, which has since resolved. He finds it difficult to find a comfortable position while sleeping.

Regarding his diabetes, he admits to having a sweet tooth and has not been eating well recently. He has been compliant with his medications. For his hypertension, he monitors his blood pressure readings at home during the week but tends to forget on weekends. He is also taking his medication for hypertension. He has early arthritis in his knee, which gets aggravated occasionally but is manageable.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. No fever or chills.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain. Tingling in right toes resolved.
• Cardiovascular: No chest pain, nausea, or vomiting.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 2/6 systolic heart murmur, stable.
• Musculoskeletal: Examination of his back reveals pain to palpation in the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

Results:

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.

Back x-ray: Normal x-ray with good bony alignment and no fracture present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain.

Lumbar strain.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports feeling a 'pop' and immediate pain while lifting heavy boxes. He has tried Tylenol and ibuprofen without significant relief.
• Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing the area and avoid strenuous activity. Refer to physical therapy for further evaluation and management.

Diabetes type 2.
• Medical Reasoning: He has been compliant with medications, but his recent hemoglobin A1c was 8.
• Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are slightly elevated.
• Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

Osteoarthritis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is managing his knee arthritis well and does not require further workup at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam and follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension. He presents for his annual exam. The patient reports a relatively stable mood with the help of Prozac and has not had any incidents related to depression recently. He mentions that his hypertension has been more of a struggle, with occasional forgetfulness to take his medication on weekends. The patient has experienced some shortness of breath during humid weather while running, but overall, his breathing function is fine.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion due to pollen.
• Cardiovascular: Shortness of breath with exertion, occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• Respiratory: Denies cough or wheezing.
• Psychiatric: Endorses depression, managed with Prozac.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological/Psychological: Appropriate mood and affect.
• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80 mmHg.

RESULTS

Electrocardiogram: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerns related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is doing well on Prozac and has not had any recent incidents.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill prescription.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encouraged the patient to continue current management strategies.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is exercising regularly and has no significant breathing issues.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon is needed.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled, despite occasional forgetfulness to take medication on weekends.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication regimen.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right middle finger pain.

HPI:

Ms. Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for an evaluation of right middle finger pain after a skiing accident over the weekend. She reports that her finger was bent backward while skiing over moguls. She has tried ice and ibuprofen for pain relief but reports continued pain.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Miralax

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Constipation
Appendectomy at age 18

EXAM:

Examination of the right middle finger shows tenderness over the distal phalanx. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right middle finger, 3 views obtained on today's visit show no fractures.

IMPRESSION:

Right index finger contusion.

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend an aluminum foam splint and a prescription for Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. The patient is advised to call and return if the pain does not improve within a week. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Anemia and fatigue.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Stephanie Diaz is a 49-year-old female with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure, kidney stones, and prior colonoscopy, who presents today for abnormal labs.

The patient reports she has been really tired and dizzy over the past couple of months. She reports these symptoms while walking a mile, going to work, and performing daily tasks. She denies any blood in her stools recently but notes she had blood in her stool about 3 years ago and had a colonoscopy for that. She denies any black, tarry stools, heavy menstrual bleeding, unintentional weight loss, or syncope.

Ms. Diaz had a colonoscopy about 3 years ago due to blood in her stool. This showed mild diverticulitis. She denies issues since that time.

Regarding her congestive heart failure, she states she is not doing well with her salt intake. This has been more of a struggle recently as she has been traveling a lot. She has noticed some swelling in her legs but nothing too extreme.

The patient denies recent issues with kidney stones. She denies low back pain, flank pain, or blood in her urine.

Ms. Diaz notes she has had some nasal congestion but attributes this to the season changing. She gets seasonal allergies but everything else has been okay. The patient denies fever, chills, sore throat, or cough.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fevers, chills, or weight loss. Endorses fatigue.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from allergies.
• Cardiovascular: Denies dyspnea.
• Respiratory: Denies cough, shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematochezia, melena.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses bilateral leg swelling.
• Neurological: Endorses dizziness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Grade 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Musculoskeletal: Trace to 1+ edema in the bilateral ankles.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram demonstrates decreased ejection fraction of 45%. Moderate mitral regurgitation.

Hemoglobin is 8.2.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Stephanie Diaz is a 49-year-old female with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure, kidney stones, and prior colonoscopy, who presents today for abnormal labs.

Anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: This is a new issue. Her recent hemoglobin level was low at 8.2, but she denies any signs of gastrointestinal bleeding or urinary tract bleeding, as well as any abnormal menstrual bleeding. Her colonoscopy from 3 years ago demonstrated mild diverticulosis.
• Additional Testing: We will order an anemia profile for further evaluation.
• Specialist Referrals: We will refer her back to gastroenterology for repeat evaluation with possible endoscopy and colonoscopy.

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: She has noticed some lower extremity edema. Her echocardiogram from 6 months ago demonstrated a reduced ejection fraction of 45%, as well as moderate mitral regurgitation.
• Medical Treatment: We will initiate Lasix 40 mg once daily, and continue with Toprol 50 mg daily and lisinopril 10 mg daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: She should continue to limit her sodium intake. I advised her to monitor her daily weights and notify me if these start to increase.

Kidney stones.
• Medical Reasoning: She as asymptomatic denies any recent flare ups.
• Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged her to continue with dietary modifications and proper hydration. She will contact me with any questions or concerns.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male who presents to the clinic today for consultation regarding a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. He initially presented to his primary care provider, Dr. Henry Howard, on 3/1/21 complaining of worsening headaches over the past few months. He denied any trouble with headaches in the past. His past clinical history is unremarkable.

Workup for worsening headaches was initiated with brain MRI and serology, where the pituitary lesion was incidentally discovered. Labs dated 3/3/21, including CBC, UNES, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, all other results were normal. MRI for the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
None

SOCIAL HISTORY

Occupation: Computer programmer
Marital status: Married for 25 years
Alcohol, smoking, and recreational drug use: None

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

None

RESULTS

MRI brain with contrast (3/4/21): Pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm.

ASSESSMENT

• Pituitary adenoma

PLAN

1. Recommend surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa.
2. Refer the patient to the eye doctor for a full exam and visual field test to map peripheral vision prior to surgery.
3. Schedule surgery through the surgery scheduler, Deborah.
4. Monitor patient's vision after surgery to assess improvement.
5. Encourage the patient to call if they have any questions or concerns.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill, a 53-year-old female, presents with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. She experienced chest pain for four days in early October 2020, which resolved on its own. The patient visited the ER during that time, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, both of which were normal. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The patient reports difficulty swallowing during the episode, which has also resolved since then. She denies any family history of GI problems and has had her gallbladder removed several years ago.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Abdomen
• Lower abdomen: No pain or tenderness upon palpation.
• Upper abdomen: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 53-year-old female who presents with a history of chest pain and difficulty swallowing, which resolved on its own. The ER ruled out heart issues with an EKG and blood tests. Possible etiologies for her symptoms include GERD, dyspepsia, esophagitis, musculoskeletal etiologies, and anxiety. The patient mentioned a stressful job transition around the time of the episode, which could have contributed to her symptoms.

Given that the patient has been asymptomatic for three months, the plan is to hold off on an EGD and monitor for any additional symptoms. The patient has elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. She will follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidney function in a patient with Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, who presents today for evaluation of kidney function. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. She has a history of difficulty with feeding and temperature regulation, as well as severe reflux. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, and physical therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist who mentioned potential kidney issues related to her syndrome.

The patient has normal wet diaper output (8-10 per day) and is drinking an adequate amount of fluids, including pea protein milk, water, and diluted juice. She is not yet walking but is crawling and attempting to take steps.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Gastrointestinal: History of severe reflux, currently managed by a GI doctor.
• Musculoskeletal: Delayed motor milestones, currently in physical therapy.
• Neurological: History of difficulty with feeding and temperature regulation.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome, presenting for evaluation of kidney function. Given the potential for congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract associated with her syndrome, we will obtain a screening kidney ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana, a 35-year-old female, presents to the clinic today for evaluation of right wrist pain. The onset of her pain began when she slipped on the stairs while doing laundry and tried to catch herself with her outstretched arms. She reports that her right wrist became swollen and painful after the fall. The patient rates her pain level as a 9 out of 10. She has been icing her wrist, using an ace wrap, and taking ibuprofen, which provided minimal relief. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Positive right wrist pain.
Skin: Positive swelling in the right wrist.
Neurological: Reports mild tingling in the right hand.

VITALS

BP: 140/70
HR: 80 bpm
Temp: 97.2°F
RR: 20 bpm

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Capillary refill is normal. 
NEURO: Normal sensation in fingers. Mild tingling reported.
MSK: Examination of the right wrist reveals swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Limited range of motion. Bony crepitus present.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist taken in office today reveals a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT

Colles' fracture of the right wrist.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with the patient in regards to her current symptoms. I have explained to her that her symptoms are consistent with a Colles' fracture. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively initially and then consider surgical options. I have advised her to wear a brace for six weeks. The patient will undergo surgery, followed by an overnight stay in the hospital. After surgery, the patient will be referred to physical therapy for further management. The patient will be prescribed 50 mg of Ultram every six hours for pain management.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will return for a follow-up appointment in one month to assess her progress and discuss the possibility of going on vacation. If her pain does not improve over the next week, she will contact the office and we will reevaluate her treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping and falling while working on his property a week ago. He felt a pop in his knee and has been experiencing pain and swelling since the incident.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, managed with 20 mg Lisinopril.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever.
Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain.
Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 150/70 mmHg
Heart rate: Not provided
Respiration: Not provided
No fever.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Respiratory
- Assessment of Respiratory Effort: Normal respiratory effort. Lungs clear bilaterally.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Right knee: Pain to palpation of the medial aspect. Pain with flexion and extension. Edema and effusion present.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee were obtained and reviewed in office today. These reveal no fractures or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Right knee MCL strain.
- Medical Treatment: Ibuprofen 800 mg twice daily for pain and inflammation. Knee brace for support. Ice therapy for 20 minutes, 3-4 times daily for swelling.
- Activity Modification: Elevate leg and limit weight-bearing activities.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg.
- Lifestyle Modification: Referral to nutritionist for dietary counseling and sodium reduction.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left shoulder pain. The onset of his pain began 3 weeks ago, without any improvement. He denies any specific injury; however, he has been renovating his basement and putting in a new ceiling. He does not recall hitting or falling onto the left shoulder. The patient states he is very active and has experienced left shoulder pain before that usually resolves with Tylenol.

The patient reports significant pain with reaching, lifting, and overhead activities. The pain is constant. He states the pain is primarily located in the left shoulder and denies it radiates down into the left arm. The patient also reports difficulty sleeping secondary to the pain. He has been taking Tylenol for pain, which provides partial relief. He denies any numbness or tingling in his left arm or fingers.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain. Neurological: Denies numbness or tingling.

VITALS

All vital signs are within the normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

MSK: Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive ROM. Tenderness over the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or AC joints. Good hand grip. Neurovascularly intact distally. Capillary refill is less than 3 seconds. Sensation is intact to light touch distally.

RESULTS

X-rays of the left shoulder were obtained and reviewed today. These are normal and reveal no fracture or bony abnormalities.

ASSESSMENT

Left shoulder pain, likely rotator cuff tendinopathy.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, I have had a lengthy discussion with him regarding his current symptoms. I have explained that his x-rays did not reveal any signs of a fracture. I have recommended that we obtain an MRI of the left shoulder to evaluate for possible rotator cuff tendinopathy. The patient was provided with a referral to formal physical therapy. He will engage in a 6-to-8-week course in order to strengthen his left shoulder. I have also advised him to take Tylenol as needed for pain. If his symptoms do not improve, we may consider a steroid injection to the left shoulder.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me once the MRI results are available for review and further discussion.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of left knee pain. The pain occurs occasionally, less than once a day, and is described as the whole kneecap feeling unstable. The pain comes and goes quickly, and the patient denies any history of injury to the knee. The patient has not taken any medications for the pain, as it does not last long. The knee pain has not significantly interfered with her daily activities, but she is concerned about an upcoming trip where she will be doing a lot of walking and line dancing.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus.

MEDICATIONS

The patient is currently taking Farxiga, Amlodipine, Lisinopril, Hydrochlorothiazide, and Metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at the left base.
Lungs: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Left knee: No ecchymosis, edema, or effusion. No pain to palpation. Full range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain - likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes mellitus.

PLAN

1. For left knee pain, prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen the muscles around the knee.
2. For hypertension, continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily and order an echocardiogram to evaluate the heart murmur.
3. For diabetes mellitus, order a Hemoglobin A1c test to assess the need for adjustments to Metformin dosage and a lipid panel.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sore throat and difficulty swallowing.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of hypertension and diabetes. Recently received COVID-19 vaccine.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient works as a cashier in a supermarket and enjoys drinking wine.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking lisinopril 20 mg daily, multi-vitamin, vitamin D, and metformin 1000 mg twice daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Reports fever, chills, and profuse sweating.
HENT: Reports sore throat, difficulty swallowing, tonsil swelling, and congestion.
Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal symptoms.

VITALS

Temperature: 100.4 degrees F.
Blood pressure: 132/80 mm Hg.
Heart rate: 84 BPM.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Face
- Examination: No pain to palpation of the frontal or maxillary sinuses.

Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat
- Examination of Nose: Edema and erythema of the nasal turbinates noted bilaterally with associated clear discharge.
- Examination of Throat: Erythema and edema of the peritonsillar space with exudates present bilaterally. The uvula is midline.

Neck
- General Examination: No thyromegaly, but there is some cervical lymphadenopathy on the right side.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Coarse rhonchi at the bases that clear with cough.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops or rubs.

RESULTS

Rapid COVID-19 test performed today in office is negative.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Sore throat and difficulty swallowing.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient has experienced sore throat, fever, chills, profuse sweating, and difficulty swallowing for 4 days. There is erythema and edema of the peritonsillar space with exudates present bilaterally as well as edema and erythema of her turbinates, bilaterally.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed treatment options today. I have stressed the importance of hydration.
- Medical Treatment: We will perform a rapid strep test today. If she is positive for strep, I will prescribe amoxicillin 500 mg 3 times a day for 10 days. Prescription for lidocaine swish and swallow provided for pain relief. Ibuprofen can also be taken for pain and fever relief.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient states her blood pressure fluctuates often. Her blood pressure today in office was 132/80 mm Hg.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed treatment options including increasing her lisinopril and diet modifications.
- Medical Treatment: Lipid panel ordered. Prescription for lisinopril 40 mg once a day is also provided.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient’s blood sugar fluctuates between 80 to 90 in the morning to 140 in the evening. She is already at 1000 mg of metformin twice a day, which she does take with meals.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of achieving a healthy lifestyle and what effects that can have on her diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: I have placed an order for a hemoglobin A1c.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low Immunoglobulin A (IgA) level.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient reports frequent colds in the wintertime, which tend to linger. Patient's family owns a donut shop. Patient denies any family history of immune deficiencies.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes, recently started on metformin.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: No fever.
Respiratory: No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Gastrointestinal: No abdominal infections or frequent diarrhea.

VITALS

No fever or other concerning vitals.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs.

Respiratory
- Auscultation of Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.

Neck
- Examination: No lymphadenopathy.

Abdominal
- Examination: Soft, non-tender.

RESULTS

Lab work consistent with IgA deficiency.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. IgA deficiency.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient's lab work shows low IgA levels, which is a common immunodeficiency. Patient does not report frequent infections or other concerning symptoms.
- Patient Education and Counseling: The nature of the diagnosis was discussed with the patient. I explained that IgA deficiency is common and many people live their entire lives without knowing they have it. I advised the patient to watch for infections that do not resolve or any changes in their abdominal tract, such as severe diarrhea.
- Medical Treatment: Additional blood work will be ordered to check other antibodies. The patient was advised to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.
- Follow-up: Patient will return for follow-up after lab work is completed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of right elbow pain. The patient has been experiencing pain in the inside of his right elbow for approximately four days. The pain is described as a 6/10 in intensity and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. The patient denies any trauma or previous injury to the right elbow. The pain has been affecting his daily activities and sleep. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery and ceramics during the pandemic.

MEDICATIONS

The patient reports that he has been taking ibuprofen for pain relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports right elbow pain.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Within normal limits.
MSK:
Examination of the right elbow: Pain to palpation along the medial aspect. Positive for pain with pronation of the forearm. Positive for pain with resistance against flexion of the left wrist.

RESULTS

X-ray images of the right elbow were obtained and reviewed in the office today. These reveal no evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

Right medial epicondylitis.

PLAN

After reviewing the patient's examination and radiographic findings today, we discussed the diagnosis of medial epicondylitis. The following treatment plan was recommended:
1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
4. Hold off on pottery work for the next couple of weeks.

The patient is scheduled for a follow-up appointment in one week to evaluate progress.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Emergency department follow up.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports history of hypertension and recent hospitalization for congestive heart failure.

MEDICATIONS

Patient reports taking Bumex 2 mg once daily, Cozaar 100 mg daily, and Norvasc 5 mg once daily.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies sleep disturbance.
Cardiovascular: Reports occasional chest pain.
Respiratory: Reports shortness of breath during exertion.
Genitourinary: No issues reported.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 128/72 mmHg
Temperature: 98.7 degrees F
Heart Rate: 72 bpm
Oxygen Saturation: 96%

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck
- General Examination: No jugular venous distention.

Cardiovascular
- Auscultation of Heart: Stable 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.

Musculoskeletal
- Examination: Trace lower extremity edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram reveals a preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild-to-moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
- Medical Reasoning: This appears to have been caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
- Patient Education and Counseling: I encouraged the patient to continue making dietary modifications, including limiting his sodium intake. Referral placed for consult with a nutritionist for education and recommendations regarding his diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue with Bumex 2 mg once daily. Patient advised to weigh himself daily and call if he gains 3 pounds in 2 days.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: This has been poorly controlled due to inconsistent compliance with medication and dietary indiscretion.
- Patient Education and Counseling: We discussed the importance of taking medications consistently and monitoring his diet.
- Medical Treatment: Continue on Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg once daily. Renal artery ultrasound ordered to rule out any issues such as renal artery stenosis.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 3 months.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Kidney stones.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a pleasant patient who presents to the clinic today for the evaluation of kidney stones. The patient was referred from his primary care physician. The onset of his pain began several days ago on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs. The pain radiates to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe. The patient reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain relief, but it has not been effective. The patient has a history of kidney stones and reports that his father also had them.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Abdominal: Reports sharp pain on the right side of the abdomen, radiating to the lower abdomen and groin.

Urinary: Reports burning sensation during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs. Positive CVA tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

The CT scan of the abdomen revealed a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. There is no evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Right kidney stone.

PLAN

We reviewed the patient's CT results in detail today. I have recommended that we treat the patient conservatively. I have prescribed the patient oxycodone 5 mg every 6 to 8 hours for pain. He may continue to take Tylenol between the oxycodone doses for any breakthrough pain. The patient will be given a strainer to use when he urinates until the stone passes. I have also recommended that we obtain a BMP, urinalysis, and urine culture to evaluate for any signs of infection.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up with me in 1 to 2 weeks to check on his progress. If his symptoms have not improved, we will discuss further treatment options including lithotripsy and ureteroscopy. The patient is advised to contact me if he experiences worsening symptoms.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Non-healing right foot ulcer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Nicholas is a 79-year-old male who presents today for evaluation of a non-healing right foot ulcer. He reports having the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The blister later became unroofed with thick, soft, and mushy skin underneath, accompanied by a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient's wife noticed a red streak coming up from the ankle along the inside portion of the calf muscle, which is hot to touch. The patient has been experiencing cramping in the calf muscle and a throbbing pain in the foot. He has also been coughing and having difficulty catching his breath while walking around the house.

The patient has been on antibiotics for six days, which initially provided some relief, but the wound has since turned black around the edges. He is diabetic with a history of diabetic neuropathy and has been experiencing blood sugar levels in the 300-400 range for the past two weeks.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy. His A1C is 6.7, and he has been well-controlled for the past two years.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys hiking and recently hiked a new trail. He wears diabetic shoes and inserts, changing the inserts every 3-4 months.

MEDICATIONS

Patient is currently on a course of antibiotics for the foot ulcer.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Patient reports fever and chills.
Cardiovascular: No chest pain.
Respiratory: Patient reports coughing and difficulty catching breath.
Skin: Patient reports non-healing right foot ulcer with black edges and red streak up the calf.
Neurological: Patient reports throbbing pain in the foot and cramping in the calf muscle.

VITALS

Slight fever.
Blood pressure and heart rate within normal limits.

PHYSICAL EXAM

CV: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.
RESPIRATORY: Patient reports coughing and difficulty catching breath.
SKIN: 2x2 cm necrotic wound on the right heel with sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, and foul odor. No bony exposure.
MSK: Pain and swelling in the calf muscle.

ASSESSMENT

1. Non-healing diabetic foot ulcer, right foot
2. Diabetes with recent blood sugar instability
3. Possible cellulitis and infection

PLAN

1. Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
2. Perform debridement of the wound in the office today.
3. Obtain a culture and consider adjusting antibiotic therapy based on results.
4. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely, with a follow-up appointment in 7 days.
5. Encourage the patient to follow up with his endocrinologist to maintain good blood sugar control and keep his A1C below 7.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in the yard. He noticed a tick bite on his right knee over a week ago, which has been causing burning and discomfort. He denies fever or chills but reports a headache and general malaise since the tick bite.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension, Diabetes

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril 20 mg daily, Metformin 1000 mg twice daily

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or body aches.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and discomfort.

VITALS

Blood pressure: 122/70 mmHg
Heart rate: 67 bpm
Temperature: 98.4°F

PHYSICAL EXAM

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs.
Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite with concern for Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with a bull's-eye rash and discomfort in the right knee after a tick bite.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice daily for 3 weeks. Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm Lyme disease diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Treatment: Continue Metformin 1000 mg twice daily. Order hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed or if symptoms worsen.
